displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you probably won’t even know what’s going on. Patient: But see doc, say between her and the wife, they’re the ninety percent around me all the time Doctor: Right, right. Patient: -and the reason why I say this. Family Member: I know what to do if you have a seizure because I’ve had a seizure – Patient: And, so, so.. Family Member: - and my aunt has seizures Doctor: Oh. Family Member: And sometimes I have to keep her from swallowing her tongue- Doctor: That’s it. Yeah- Family Member: -by putting the spoon under there, so just letting it flow through. Doctor: -and again point six percent chance is really rare, but it’s probably if I look at all the side effect list it’s the one that would scare me the most if I was reading that form,

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Um hum. Doctor: But sometimes we think about vaccine therapy because we know kind of in this sort of early stage of things about to break through- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: That’s actually the perfect place for vaccine therapy to be. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because if you have the flu for example- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: You sure as heck don’t give the flu shot after the fact. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: Because nothing’s going to happen. Family Member: Happen. Right. Doctor: But if you know that you’re susceptible to it, you know, something’s going to happen.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: which is a combination sort of Tylenol with an opiate drug. Obviously, for any narcotics you take enough of it you don’t need it, you can get addicted. It’s just you know all the rage that’s going on Patient: Right. Doctor: but our cancer patients are in a different pool. You have cancer not treated, you’re in pain, we take narcotics. It’s at this moment the best option. Okay? Patient: Okay, yes. Doctor: So, don’t sit there and say wow, I haven’t taken it in five days, I can’t stand it anymore and now I’m gonna pop it. That’s not the life I want you to live. Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: I know. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Gee, you and every other guy I have in my practice which is why I say this. Patient: Oh, Okay. Doctor: Please just recognize that your quality of life will be so much better Patient: Okay.

Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. And you know some of what we’re really talking about is what do we do if we tell you that. Does that bring up questions? Patient: In other words where do we go from here? Doctor: What is your understanding or what Dr. G__ talked about. Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it?

Patient: Oh. Doctor: Are you gettin’ an award or somethin’? Patient: No! It’s just that, you know – Doctor: Recognition? Patient: I’m the, I’m the guy. My company has a guy. Healthcare Professional 2: You’re the guy? (Laughs) Doctor: He’s the guy! Patient: I went, I went through rickets. You know what I’m sayin’? Doctor: Okay. Well, then you go to that. Then, it’s important. Pick some other time. Patient: Well, well, well, you know what? You know what? They do a registration on Sunday, and Monday is really the big day. Doctor: Okay! Patient: You followin’ what I’m sayin’? Do you? Doctor: They’ll see your face. You’ll be there.

Family Member: Mm-hmm. Doctor: Plenty of time! Plenty of time. Patient: So, so, so it’s not bad news that …. Doctor: No, I don’t think it’s bad news at all. We were all kinda, “Ohhhhhh. Maybe there’s a thing in the liver or whatever.” You’re good. Patient: Good. Family Member: Oh, good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, deep breath on everyone’s part. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll have M___ come right in. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Soooo good to see you. Family Member: Thank you.

Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Better than four point two. Right. But you know your scans still show two new spots in your head. Not brain. Skull. Family Member: Right. Uh huh. Doctor: So I feel like something’s definitely about to happen. You know? Break, breakthrough. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Which is why I think the last conversation was on the vaccine therapy, Provenge. So I know we gave, we gave you all that information. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I’m not sure he gave it to you? Family Member: No. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: No. He did not. Hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know the paperwork that we usually do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The, it, the biggest side effect can be dropping of blood counts. So what you’re gonna have to do… Doctor: No. The best way to prevent it is we will give you a shot the second day, okay, the day after your chemo to um help prevent the blood counts from dropping. Patient: So this will be the last chemo? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: For this particular one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then next time we’ll start the new one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay and that will be uh so you’ll have to come two days in a row every three weeks.

Patient: Are you smoking? Come on. Family Member: Whoa wait a minute. Patient: There’s a disconnect you change your… Family Member: Did you see my face? Patient: Probably mine too but uh – but who did we hear routine would be six? Who told us six? Family Member: I don’t know… Patient: Was that Dr. Y or W? Family Member: I don’t know. Wayne maybe. I don’t know. Patient: Somebody made a comment that… Doctor: I think you know so all the studies, they try to go up to ten. They try to go up to ten. So we just try to chunk – you’re a little off cycle because you know we started off with the vitamin C thing so three more and then… Family Member: Seriously, we need three more? Doctor: Yeah. We want ten total.

Patient: I wasn’t aware of- Doctor: Like. No. I think it’s okay. I think K___ has everything. So we’re good. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. I just want to double check. You scared the heck out of me last time. So I’m just gonna I don’t know keep an eye on you just a little bit closer - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: -until I’m confident that I can let you go for three months. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. It’s all good. Don’t run away. I’ll bring back K___ and the nutrition book. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. And I had peeing, but very little at the time. So they said it’s not doing it properly, so they put catheter back in. And they told me they shouldn’t have taken out. So the urologist told me; they should have flushed it and anyway, so. Doctor: So they kept you in overnight that time? Patient: Uh no, no. Doctor: So you were only in and out for what time? Patient: Only in and everything was right. There was only one. I came around three-thirty and by eleven you know I’m home. And I felt okay because then when I started peeing again properly there’s no problem anymore. Family Member: They also took; uh they checked the kidneys. Patient: Yeah, they checked the kidneys; the kidneys were improving, but uh - Doctor: So you were in the hospital once or twice? Patient: Twice. Doctor: Overnight? Patient: No. Let’s say over seven days. Doctor: And you were just in E.R. Patient: I was just E.R.

Patient: There is? Doctor: There is. Yeah, yeah, there's one I think that's purple and I'm pretty sure there's a blue one. Again, I peruse the poop in the mouth aisle, because I don't like to recommend things that you can't get access to. You know, when it sounds good on paper and in the textbooks, and then you go to Meijer, you go to Rite Aid and you're like, “what are you talking about, I've never seen it”. So I will peruse the same store as you guys shop at because if I don't see it then how are you going to play it? So I do know Crest has one that says no alcohol that's a blue and I'm pretty sure Listerine is purple that's a no alcohol, so those are two really good ones. You know I’d still cut it a little bit with the water. Family Member 1: What about toothpaste? Doctor: Same with a lot of the whitening and all that is very harsh on the gums. You know there's Sensodyne, which is very calming. Family Member 1: I have to do a prescription because Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member 1: Well I’m on blood thinners every day. Patient: So M___ is the next person to come in? Doctor: M____'s coming right in. Family Member 2: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay that’s where you switched to? Patient: That’s where I’ve been going and then try to talk to uh I tried to talk to her Monday when I came in I can’t think of her name, H____. I talked to her. She said Mr. F____ you haven’t done anything wrong. And I said I know it. So you know what I’m saying? Somebody was stealing from me. So I said why couldn’t I -I can’t come here. That’s any policy. Any pharmacy you go to that I’ve ever been to, you have to have your ID. Couldn’t anyone come up there and get your stuff. And then I had told them two weeks before. Doctor: But you’ve never had ID for a long time and they were doing you a special favor right… Patient: No I… Doctor: …by giving you. Now you have ID. Patient: I’ve been having it, doctor, I’ve been disappointed though uh when I put, two weeks after I put in there do not let anyone come and pick up my medication if it’s not me. Why would you still let somebody pay but they said it was another girl cuz C____ the young lady that said I do know – Doctor: Mmm. Patient: - said no it wasn’t us. It must have been the girl somebody new but she was at the office where they explained that to her. Doctor: Alright so I’ll you a new script then. Patient: But anyway… Doctor: And you’re gonna get it filled at H____? Patient: Oh yeah but anyway, but anyway uh Dr. B____ the, the, the I think he’s short. I can’t think of his name. Anyway, he told me to talk to him. It’s a Chinese guy that that that denied me, but his boss…

Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know. Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something.
